makers.displaydate: 1912–1992; born Los Angeles, CA; died New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: John Cage, 1912–1992; born Los Angeles, CA; died New York, NY
Published by Crown Point Press, established 1962
Printed by Lilah Toland, American, active 1978–1983

texts.textentryhtml: John Cage is known primarily as a composer of music, but he was also an accomplished printmaker, and his work in both media exerted a tremendous influence on a generation of visual artists, including Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg. For the Changes and Disappearances series, Cage dropped pieces of string onto a metal etching plate to produce lines, allowing gravity and chance to determine the forms those lines took (a technique he borrowed from Marcel Duchamp and Jean Arp). Lines that landed outside of the area to be printed he deemed "disappearances."

Here, Cage alludes to Marcel Duchamp’s technique for chance-based composition by dropping pieces of string onto a metal etching plate to produce lines, allowing gravity to determine their form; lines that landed outside of the plate were deemed "disappearances." The desire to represent indeterminacy, motion, and the experience of chance and fate motivated Cage’s methods throughout his practice.
texts.remarks: Migration and Material Alchecmy: Marquand Mather Rotation
